Problem Description:
You’re organizing a two-day event featuring a total of ten seminars, each
focused on a topic in Artificial Intelligence (AI), Biology, or
Mathematics. Each day is divided into three time slots — morning,
midday, and afternoon — and there are four available rooms in which
the seminars can be held.
Every seminar needs a spot on the schedule, and no room can host more
than one seminar during any given time slot.
There are several constraints tied to the seminar topics and venue
logistics. To start with, seminars on AI should only be scheduled
in the morning or midday — these talks aren't suitable for the
afternoon. For Biology, you’ll need to make sure that its seminars
are spread out — they can't all take place in the same room; at
least two different rooms must be used for them.
Also note that Room 4 is off-limits at midday, regardless of the day
 — that slot is unavailable for use in that room entirely.
As for the Math seminars, you’ll need to ensure that no two of them
are happening at the same time, even if they’re in different rooms.
There are also a few seminar-specific instructions: Seminar 5 must be
scheduled on the second day, but it can't be placed in the morning
slot. Additionally, Seminar 6 and Seminar 7 should be assigned to
the same room, but not on the same day — they need to be spaced 
out across the two days.

### TASK
Create the instance template (define predicates and domains).

seminar(1..10).
topic("AI"; "Bio"; "Math").
day(1; 2).
timeslot("morning"; "midday"; "afternoon").
room(1..4).

Problem Description:
You are tasked with solving the Asprilo warehouse logistics problem.
The environment is a 2D grid containing robots, shelves, picking stations, and products.
The input specifies the initial positions of all entities, the inventory of products on shelves, and the customer orders.

The objective is to fulfill all orders within a specified time horizon.
Robots must:
1. Move through the grid to reach shelves.
2. Pick up shelves that contain the required products.
3. Transport the shelves to the designated picking stations.
4. Deliver the required quantity of products at the station.
5. Return the shelf to a storage location (or leave it at a valid spot).

Constraints:
1. Robots can move in the four cardinal directions (North, South, East, West).
2. Robots cannot move through obstacles or other robots (vertex and edge collision constraints).
3. A robot can carry at most one shelf at a time.
4. A shelf can be carried by at most one robot at a time.
5. Pickup and Putdown actions can only occur when a robot is at the same location as a shelf.
6. Delivery actions can only occur when a robot carrying a shelf is at a picking station.

The solution must output the sequence of actions (move, pickup, putdown, deliver) for each robot.

### TASK
Create the instance template (define predicates and domains).
time(1..horizon). direction((X,Y)) :- X=-1..1, Y=-1..1, |X+Y|=1. nextto((X,Y),(DX,DY),(X',Y')) :- direction((DX,DY)), position((X,Y)), position((X',Y')), (X,Y)=(X'-DX,Y'-DY), (X',Y')=(X+DX,Y+DY).

select a processor, a graphics card, and a storage unit from a shortlist provided by the
procurement office. Each category contains exactly three items, all of which vary in
cost and advertised performance ratings. While only one item from each class can be
chosen, it's not as simple as picking the best in each—certain budgetary and performance
considerations are in play.
Let’s start with the CPUs: the X9 offers moderate speed (score 95) for $300, the ZetaCore is the
highest-performing chip (score 120) and costs $500, and the Alpha8, while slightly below
ZetaCore in speed (score 110), still carries a premium at $450. Meanwhile, your GPU choices
include QuasarRTX (130 points, $700), NovaX (125 points, $600), and the more modest GammaGTX
(90 points, $450). For storage, there’s UltraSSD (100 points, $250), FusionDrive (95 points,
$300), and the budget-tier MegaHDD (60 points, $200).
One of the directives from IT leadership is that your most costly component must also be
the one delivering the greatest performance in your final selection—presumably to justify
budget overruns. However, it's frowned upon to pick the single highest-rated part from each
of the three categories; evidently, they want to avoid over-spec’d builds. There’s also a
guideline about balance: while you don’t need to match prices perfectly, no component
should differ in cost from another by more than $250. Consider that a soft constraint, they'll
reject your build if that balance is off.
Also, while the graphics team claims that a powerful GPU helps with rendering, you’re not
allowed to have a GPU that outperforms the CPU. A constraint buried in the procurement
notes says that the Alpha8 CPU isn’t validated to work with the NovaX GPU due to BIOS
issues. And for some reason, the FusionDrive isn’t available unless you’re pairing it
with the ZetaCore.
Despite the abundance of high-performance hardware, you’ll need to select carefully to
stay within these constraints.

### TASK
Create the instance template (define predicates and domains).

cpu("X9"; "ZetaCore"; "Alpha8").
gpu("QuasarRTX"; "NovaX"; "GammaGTX").
storage("UltraSSD"; "MegaHDD"; "FusionDrive").
cost("X9", 300; "ZetaCore", 500; "Alpha8", 450).
cost("QuasarRTX", 700; "NovaX", 600; "GammaGTX", 450).
cost("UltraSSD", 250; "MegaHDD", 200; "FusionDrive", 300).
perf("X9", 95; "ZetaCore", 120; "Alpha8", 110).
perf("QuasarRTX", 130; "NovaX", 125; "GammaGTX", 90).
perf("UltraSSD", 100; "MegaHDD", 60; "FusionDrive", 95).

Problem Description:
Procurement has turned philosophical: “Don’t always buy the most powerful; buy the right
powerful.” You’re assembling a balanced data-processing workstation, and the specs you must
navigate are less about raw numbers and more about proportionality.
CPUs — FalconX ($600, 125 pts), CoreZen ($500, 115 pts), EcoMini ($300, 90 pts)
GPUs — TitanZ ($700, 135 pts), MidlineGT ($500, 100 pts), Pixie ($400, 95 pts)
Drives — FlashNova ($250, 110 pts), Terabox ($300, 100 pts), BudgetDisk ($150, 60 pts)
Each component must be selected from its category. But the trick is in how these relate.
The component with the middle performance value (not highest or lowest) must be the cheapest
among the three selected parts.
If you pick a CPU worth more than $500, you can’t pair it with the Pixie GPU.
Avoid configurations where the performance spread (max - min) exceeds 50 points.
If you select the FlashNova SSD, the GPU must score at least 100.
You must select exactly two components whose price is above $300 and the GPU’s performance
must fall between the CPU and drive—i.e., not the highest or lowest.

Problem Description:
You are tasked with solving the Sokoban puzzle.
The environment is a grid where some cells contain stones, some are empty (clear), and some are walls.
There is a player (pusher) at a specific starting location.
The goal is to push all stones onto designated goal locations.

The rules are:
1. The player can move to an adjacent clear square (North, South, East, West).
2. The player can push a stone to an adjacent square if the square behind the stone is clear.
3. You cannot pull stones.
4. You cannot push two stones at once.
5. You cannot move through walls or stones.

The solution must output the sequence of actions (move or push) to reach the goal state where all stones are on goal squares.

Create the instance template (define predicates and domains).

The media lab is assembling a suite of machines for real-time 3D rendering, and while performance
is paramount, the budget committee is breathing down everyone’s neck about excess spending.

and power supplies. Each component is annotated with its wattage and price tag, and while you
can technically pick anything, there are tight constraints.
Here’s what’s on the list:
CPUs — BoltX (wattage: 85W, $400), HydraPro (125W, $550), LiteCore (60W, $350)
GPUs — StormZ (180W, $800), Nebula9 (150W, $650), VegaLite (95W, $500)
Power Supplies — PowerMax750 (capacity: 750W, $200), Eco600 (600W, $150), Titan900 (900W, $250)
You’ll need to ensure that the total system draw—i.e., the sum of selected CPU and GPU
wattages—remains at least 100W below the selected power supply’s maximum output.
Apparently, this is to avoid overloading under peak load bursts.
There’s another thing: the most power-hungry part (by wattage) in your final configuration
must also be the most expensive. That rule is apparently about cost justification.
Compatibility is a minefield: HydraPro doesn’t play nicely with VegaLite due to thermal
constraints, and if you pick Eco600, you can’t use StormZ, which requires better voltage
regulation. Oh, and you’re not allowed to pick all three cheapest components. Also, no pair of 
selected parts can differ in cost by more than $400.

Problem Description:
You’re tasked with planning an intensive two‑day research symposium featuring
ten seminars, each devoted to one of four fields—Artificial Intelligence,
Biology, Mathematics, or Chemistry. Both days are sliced into four
segments — morning, late morning, early afternoon, and late afternoon — and
you have five distinct rooms at your disposal.
Naturally, every seminar must find its place in the programme, and no room ever
hosts more than one talk at once. To keep the flow manageable and give each
room a little breathing room, no room may be booked for more than half of the 
time slots in a single day, nor may it run back‑to‑back sessions without a break.
Also, bear in mind that Room 3 goes offline once afternoon begins,
and Room 5 lacks any projection equipment, so any seminar requiring slides
won’t fit there.
Speaking of equipment, both AI and Mathematics talks rely on a working projector,
and the AI presentations have an early‑day preference: they’re confined to the
morning or late‑morning slots. Biology seminars, by contrast, must be sprinkled
across the two days — never exclusively in one — and you cannot have two bio talks
taking place simultaneously. Chemistry talks, on the other hand, are social
in time but solitary in space: no two of them may ever occupy the same
room. Additionally, you can’t mix a Bio session with a Chem
session under the same roof on a given day, so those pairings must stay apart.
There’s also a special framing requirement: the symposium must open and close
with mathematics, so the very first seminar and the final seminar of are both
mathematics events. Beyond that, you’ll want to avoid empty slots
unless there’s simply no alternative. Each time segment should showcase as
many different topics as possible, and while it’s fine for Biology and Chemistry
to overlap with other sessions, no more than two Bio‑or‑Chem seminars may ever
run at the same moment.
With these guidelines in mind, you’ll blend room capacities, projector access, 
temporal preferences, and topic distributions into a single, seamless schedule 
that serves presenters, attendees, and the venues’ technical quirks without leaving
unnecessary gaps.

### TASK
Create the instance template (define predicates and domains).

seminar(1..10). topic("AI"; "Bio"; "Math"; "Chem"). day(1; 2). timeslot("morning"; "late morning"; "early afternoon"; "late afternoon"). room(1..5). follows("morning","late morning";"late morning", "early afternoon";"early afternoon", "late afternoon"). -projector(R) :- room(R), R = 5. firstSession("morning", 1). lastSession("late afternoon", 2).

You’re tasked with planning an intensive two‑day research symposium featuring
ten seminars, each devoted to one of four fields—Artificial Intelligence,
Biology, Mathematics, or Chemistry. Both days are sliced into four
segments — morning, late morning, early afternoon, and late afternoon — and
you have five distinct rooms at your disposal.
Naturally, every seminar must find its place in the programme, and no room ever
hosts more than one talk at once. To keep the flow manageable and give each
room a little breathing room, no room may be booked for more than half of the 
time slots in a single day, nor may it run back‑to‑back sessions without a break.
Also, bear in mind that Room 3 goes offline once afternoon begins,
and Room 5 lacks any projection equipment, so any seminar requiring slides
won’t fit there.
Speaking of equipment, both AI and Mathematics talks rely on a working projector,
and the AI presentations have an early‑day preference: they’re confined to the
morning or late‑morning slots. Biology seminars, by contrast, must be sprinkled
across the two days — never exclusively in one — and you cannot have two bio talks
taking place simultaneously. Chemistry talks, on the other hand, are social
in time but solitary in space: no two of them may ever occupy the same
room. Additionally, you can’t mix a Bio session with a Chem
session under the same roof on a given day, so those pairings must stay apart.
There’s also a special framing requirement: the symposium must open and close
with mathematics, so the very first seminar and the final seminar of are both
mathematics events. Beyond that, you’ll want to avoid empty slots
unless there’s simply no alternative. Each time segment should showcase as
many different topics as possible, and while it’s fine for Biology and Chemistry
to overlap with other sessions, no more than two Bio‑or‑Chem seminars may ever
run at the same moment.
With these guidelines in mind, you’ll blend room capacities, projector access, 
temporal preferences, and topic distributions into a single, seamless schedule 
that serves presenters, attendees, and the venues’ technical quirks without leaving
unnecessary gaps.
